conclusion: Object starts moving under horizontal force F; graph shows acceleration vs. displacement.
Graph has x-axis as displacement and y-axis as acceleration with points x1, x2, x3.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with time.
From x=0 to x1, acceleration is constant at a0.
From x1 to x2, acceleration decreases linearly from a0 to 0.
From x2 to x3, acceleration decreases linearly to a negative value.
Need to find velocity at x = x1.
Object starts from rest at x = 0.
Use v dv/dx = a to relate acceleration to velocity.
Set up differential equation v dv/dx = a0 and integrate.
Integration gives (1/2)v^2 = a0 x + C; C = 0 at x=0, v=0.
At x = x1, v = sqrt(2 a0 x1).
Consider entire motion from x=0 to x=x1; acceleration is constant.
Verify no other forces like friction; assume only force F.
Final velocity at x1 is sqrt(2 a0 x1).
